Session was to cover:
• Access to Cloud instance (pending access from last meeting). We would be working on the Dev instance.
• They want to create CC based forms - discussed if they want to have standalone forms - or Unified Authoring. These forms are included in 2-3 pages, so standalone forms may be useful.
• AEP configuration - Need clarity on the existing structure to which forms are to be submitted - currently on Dev it is blank/empty. - <@U0213T59LMN> could you add more details/info which we need from customer.
• They do not have OOTB collateral (CC templates/themes). Created a template for blank CC form. <@U05TSNKRNP8> to validate the setup - if we are able to create the form now.
*Action items from last session:*
• _Requirements Documentation: Write and share a document listing the requirements and scope for the forms, including details such as submission destination and potential reuse across pages. (Jennifer Rogers, David Lopez)_ => *They mentioned that it is a simple flow with data submitted to RTCDP - with no prefill.*
• _Access Provisioning: Add Vijay Kumar and Sudhanshu to the AEM dev environment with appropriate admin access profiles to enable configuration and setup activities. (David Lopez)_ => *Required access provided to Mayank, Harman, Sudhanshu*
• _Pipeline Impact Confirmation:_ _Follow up with Paul to confirm whether running the dev pipeline will have any unintended impact on the current environment or recent releases. (Jennifer Rogers)_ => *They mentioned that we can use Dev - <@U0213T59LMN> could you help track/get confirmation on this in next call (maybe reviewing the Github repos for the environments would help - if they are connected)*
• Slack Channel Setup: Create a new Slack channel dedicated to the forms engagement and invite all relevant team members for ongoing collaboration. (Vijay Kumar, Arun) => *Channel created - Slack channel created in Adobe Enterprise Support: #aemcs-brightline-forms*
• *Weekly Meeting Coordination:* Coordinate and finalize a weekly meeting time that accommodates both the East Coast and India-based team members, ideally between 7:00 AM and 10:00 AM Pacific. (Vince, Arun) => *Second meeting was scheduled - so assuming this is done. <@U0213T59LMN> / <@W5HEU5M7Y> could you help confirm if we have a weekly scheduled meeting now.*

She also mentioned that it would help if we could provide more opportunities with other forms - with lower threshold to evaluate.

• *Access Issues in Mercury Marine Environments:* Mayank, Andy, and others discussed ongoing access limitations in the Mercury Marine QA and stage environments, with Christy and Sarah assisting in troubleshooting and planning to adjust permissions to enable form creation and configuration.
• *Pipeline Execution and Core Component Deployment:* Rahul Kumar, Christy, Arun, and Andy discussed the need to rerun the Cloud Manager pipeline in the QA environment to ensure that core components and templates are properly deployed, with Christy initiating the pipeline run and the team agreeing to verify results after completion.
• *Coordination of Communication Channels:* Arun and Andy clarified the use of communication channels, confirming that a Slack channel or Teams chat would be used for ongoing updates and coordination regarding environment access and pipeline status.
• *Planning for Next Steps and Form Walkthrough:* Andy and Mayank agreed to plan a walkthrough of the first form creation on the next call, contingent on successful access and pipeline deployment, with the team aligning on the QA environment for development.
:todo_done: *

Had a connect with Terry Mah for a new Forms opportunity
• PWC (Chicago) wants to leverage Forms for their Audit process - worldwide with ~ 100K users
• Render the form in headless mode in their .Net # application
• Pre-sales opp. - started last week - probably - CS + OnPrem for China
Key requirements:
• Store the form definition in a separate store
• Have a *list of fragments* (currently we do not have an API for this) - managed with an existing *React Application which has fragment search based on tags* (similar to JPMC use-case - <@W4R5LUPK3>)
• Support for *versioning* and *locking* - where a workflow is used for *review* and unlocks the fragments for specific authors
• Submission is to a DB (Terry mentioned that he did not expect complexity here)
• Currently forms are defined in Excel - which is not an easy interface. They have their own React application based authoring interface - but our UE/CC editor has those capabilities.
• Needs a custom composite component where we have form elements inside a checkbox group (a similar requirement came from UBS in past).
• Runtime is a .Net application where the form is to be rendered based on JSON stored in their store.
• multilingual forms/translation requirements (supported in headless)
They have an aggressive timeline - with 110 content fragments to be migrated in 3 months

Rishi shared:
• Recent demo done for HomeDepot - will be sharing the sandbox with Terry
• Code Sandbox to play around with the React rendition of forms
:todo_done: *

*
Go-live was scheduled for 10th September. On 5th September, a fragment localization issue was reported, which blocked the release. The issue was resolved, and a private release was patched to their environment on 10th September as promised

More details here, <https://dmasupport.slack.com/archives/C05UWBPNSTF/p1757059211088049>
:todo_done: *

*
• *Custom Indexing*: Engineering discovered that a custom Lucene index was overriding the default, leading to inefficient queries. Renaming and copying standard rules improved performance. These changes are being tested in QA and will be rolled out to production.
• *401 Authentication Errors*: Engineering observed inconsistent token errors across environments. Errors seem reduced after indexing updates, but monitoring continues with Adobe support involved.
• *PDF Form Conversion*: Engineering explained that XFA-based PDFs aren’t supported. Conversion to XDP is required, though some PDFs fail conversion. An Acrobat Pro license is requested to allow direct edits when conversion isn’t possible.
• *Data Binding & Validation*: Engineering identified a misconfigured property causing validation failures. Emphasis placed on correct field naming and binding consistency. Fixes are underway.
• *Testing automation*: Engineering provided the recordings for the automation tool for customers to review.
:todo_done: *

*
• *Pipeline Verification and Dependency Troubleshooting:* Mayank, Christy Bastian, Andy Kluck, and Shraddha collaborated to verify the deployment pipeline, check component versions, and troubleshoot missing dependencies in the QA environment, ensuring the correct setup before proceeding with form creation.
• *Template and Form Creation in AEM:* Mayank guided Christy Bastian and Andy Kluck through the process of creating templates and adaptive forms in AEM, demonstrating template creation, enabling, and usage for form authors, and confirming successful visibility and access.
• *Marketo Engage Cloud Configuration Setup:* Andy Kluck, Christy Bastian, and the team worked together to locate, create, and authenticate the Marketo Engage cloud configuration in the Mercury Marine folder, ensuring the connection was established and visible in the environment.
• *Adaptive Form Building and Data Mapping:* Mayank, Andy Kluck, and Shraddha demonstrated the process of building adaptive forms using the Marketo Engage schema, mapping required fields, configuring validation, and utilizing the rule editor for conditional logic.
• *Theme and Styling Challenges for Mercury Forms:* Andy Kluck raised concerns about the absence of Mercury-specific themes in QA, and Mayank and the team discussed options for creating or copying themes, embedding forms, and aligning form styling with the Mercury website.
• *Layout Customization and Editor Usability:* Andy Kluck and the team explored the adaptive form editor's layout features, attempting to create two-column layouts and adjust field spans, while troubleshooting usability challenges and planning follow-up actions.
:todo_done: *

• Accessibility Issue related to value not being tagged in accessibility tag tree for bottom caption was discussed.  It was fixed in SP23 . They tested it on SP22 document generation service. We have suggested them to test it on SP23.
• Wells Fargo also reported a regression where path objects are visible in the content tree in Acrobat for checkboxes boundaries, which they believe was fixed in SP19. Support will open a Jira ticket to verify whether this issue can be reproduced internally.
:todo_done: *

*Lead Gen Form Variant*: Suggested adding another variant with a hyperlink in the header bar. Team mentioned it’s not critical right now, but added to the backlog.
*Conversion Rate*: First-order form (lead gen) conversion remains steady at ~24–25%.
*Wilson Results (Aug 14–27 vs. previous period)*:
• Lead signups ↑ *163%* (2.5K → 6.6K)
• Revenue from lead gen ↑ *156%* ($110K → $284K)
• Contribution to total site revenue ↑ from *~5%* → *~9%*

:todo_done: *

• *Newsletter Subscription Form Optimization Opportunity:* Rahul Kumar presented a new Site Optimizer opportunity related to the newsletter subscription form, explaining the low conversion rates and suggesting two variants for improvement, while Clare and Paul inquired about value calculation and exportability for testing.
    ◦ *Opportunity Identification:* Rahul Kumar detailed the analysis of the newsletter subscription form, noting that out of 134,000 page views in 60 days, only 25,000 users reached the form and just 100 interacted with it, indicating a low conversion rate.
    ◦ *Suggested Variants:* Rahul Kumar described two system-generated suggestions: moving the form’s call-to-action (CTA) to the top of the page (above the fold) or implementing a sticky widget on the side, aiming to increase visibility and lead conversions.
    ◦ *Value Calculation Methodology:* Clare asked about the value assigned to the opportunity, and Rahul Kumar explained that the annual value is calculated using CPA values, traffic estimates, and projected increases in conversions, with the ability to adjust the lead value as needed.
    ◦ *Export and Testing Capabilities:* Clare inquired about exporting the suggested variants to Adobe Target for AB testing. Rahul Kumar clarified that direct export is not currently available, but Hyman outlined the roadmap to enable integration with Experience Manager and, eventually, Adobe Target for experimentation.
*Follow-up tasks:*
• *Extrapolated Metrics Transparency:* Add detailed explanations in reporting to clarify how extrapolated metrics and business case values (e.g., value assigned to newsletter signups) are calculated, including the underlying metrics and time periods. (Rahul Kumar, Hyman)

:todo_done: *

• *Introduction:* Michael, Simon Habtu, Emily, John, and Dallas discussed the integration of AEM forms on <http://ups.com|ups.com>. The meeting aimed to explore the best ways to leverage AEM forms, compare them with Marketo forms, and understand the backend connections required for implementation. 
• *AEM Forms vs Marketo Forms:* Michael and Emily clarified that <http://ups.com|ups.com> should move 100% to AEM forms, reserving Marketo forms for Marketo pages. Simon Habtu explained the option of using Marketo for backend connections to Salesforce, but the focus remained on AEM forms. 
• *Forms Creation and Integration:* Meghali, the technical consultant, demonstrated the process of creating forms on EDS, including the use of Universal Editor and Forms Experience Builder. The session covered the core features, rapid form generation, and publishing forms on EDS. 
• *Themes and Customisation:* Dallas inquired about creating themes for different business requirements. Meghali and Manu explained the process of creating and integrating themes within the EDS environment, highlighting the flexibility and customisation options available. 
• *API Integration and Data Storage:* Dallas raised concerns about storing data and the best practices for API calls. Vijay Kumar explained the support for API integration, including the use of API integration tools and the importance of configuring client credentials for authentication. 
• *Forms Experience Builder:* Vijay Kumar showcased the Forms Experience Builder, demonstrating its AI-based capabilities for creating forms from screenshots and updating fields. The tool aims to speed up form authoring and enhance user experience.
• *Next Steps and Follow-Up:* Simon Habtu and Michael discussed the next steps, including enabling API integration in the dev environment and setting up a follow-up call to discuss the scale of form creation activities. The team also considered the possibility of participating in the VIP program for forms. 

:todo_done: *

*
• *Marketo Integration and Hidden Field Mapping:* Andy and Mayank discussed the process of mapping hidden fields from AEM forms to Marketo, including the use of assignment rules based on operating units and the need for logic to populate these fields according to website region, with input from Christy and future planning for additional regions.
• *Custom Object Field Handling Between Salesforce and Marketo:* Andy, Mayank, and Sarah clarified the handling of custom object fields originating from Salesforce, discussing the need to link custom objects to the lead object for visibility in AEM forms and outlining a workaround for mapping fields such as form name and UTM parameters.
• *AEM Form Styling and Theme Management:* Christy, Devendra, Mayank, Jonathan, and Heidi discussed the process for managing AEM form themes, including the relevance of reference theme packages, the use of core components, and strategies for aligning form styling with site branding.
• *UTM Parameter Handling and Pre-Release Feature Enablement:* Mayank, Andy, Christy, and others discussed the process for enabling UTM parameter handling in AEM forms, including the need to activate pre-release features in the environment and the steps required for deployment and testing.
• *Translation Options for AEM Forms:* Sarah, Christy, Mayank, Heidi, and Jonathan discussed translation strategies for AEM forms, covering both machine and human translation options, integration with existing web translation workflows, and the use of Accolade for content translation.
:todo_done: *

• *Custom Indexing*: Customer confirmed previous indexing issue resolved by creating a custom Lucene index. Unique index names don’t override OOTB, but similar names do. File deletion tests validated improved performance. Uncertainty remains about safe index removal.
• *Forms Experience Builder Conversion*: Customer demonstrated metadata not updating when replacing PDFs in place. Workaround requires uploading into a new folder, which resets metadata. Builder provided field binding sometimes fails to map duplicates correctly. September batch includes 10–20 forms pending conversion.
• *Signature Field Deletion*: Engineering showed prompt-based deletion of signature fields works. Prompts can be refined to better target specific fields.
• *JWT Authentication Issue*: Customer reported 401 errors on first servlet call using JWT tokens, with success on retry. Adobe is assisting with troubleshooting via enhanced logging. Current workaround uses retries, but a permanent fix is needed. Issue escalated beyond P2 due to performance testing delays.
:todo_done: *

• *Capturing ECID, FBCLID, and GCLID in Marketo Forms:* Andy Kluck, Mayank, Arun, and others discussed the technical process and challenges of capturing ECID, FBCLID, and GCLID values in Marketo forms, including the current setup, data sources, and the need for further investigation and possible custom functions.
• *Developer Access and Repository Workflow:* Christy, Mayank, Arun, and others coordinated on providing developer access in Cloud Manager and clarified the correct workflow for code changes, including repository structure and permissions.
• *Custom Function Development and Reusability:* Andy Kluck, Christy, Arun, and others discussed the need for custom functions to capture analytics parameters, concerns about ongoing maintenance, and the plan for the platform team to develop reusable solutions.
• *Translation Process for Sites:* Mayank and Christy briefly revisited the topic of site translation processes, with Christy committing to provide more information in the next meeting.
:todo_done: *

*Use Case Summary*
Royal wants an authoring experience where ship staff can use a module-based builder to drag and drop daily activities, ads, and other components—sourced live from a connected database of ship activities and amenities—into a template for each ship and cruise day, ensuring the most up-to-date content is always reflected; the process should automate the generation of a final PDF document for printing or download, eliminating manual updates and syncing issues while supporting thousands of unique daily itineraries across their fleet.

*Notes*
• It is a pre-sales engagement.
• It’s an IC use case. IC Editor was demoed and received well.
• They want to see the associate UI demo as well before making the final decision.
:todo_done: *

*
• They have a massive daily batch based invoice generation use case. 
• They generate around 13M PDFs per day. 
• Currently, they use OpenText Exstream which is a robust system and they also use RICOH for certain other PDF solutions. 
• They presented their use case requirements. They don’t have any major pain points with the existing solution. 
• They are an existing AEM Assets & Sites, AEM customer. 
• They are exploring alternatives to see if there is a better price point from what they are currently paying. 
• Arun gave an overview of Forms solution.
:todo_done: *

• Forms Team showcased accessibility issues for few of their forms which had high traffic. 
• Shared the issues with Michelle which she will hand over to relevant team.
• Michelle mentioned that their forms team is small, with legacy UI and they avoid changes due to lack of expertise.
• We also asked if they had any critical forms that they would want us to look at, they mentioned their “Book a flight” form is the critical one.

• *Forms Search Inconsistency*: Customer reported inconsistent search results in Forms Experience Builder. Engineering confirmed issue occurs across both main interface and properties dialog. Workarounds (full path/name) help but don’t solve root cause. Engineering committed to investigate and fix.
• *401 Authentication Errors*: Arneh identified conflicting cookies and headers as the likely cause of 401s. Recommended removing cookies from requests. Customer will check with middleware team. Engineering to provide cookie details and logs.
• *Offshore Developer Support*: Engineering offered direct support to customer’s offshore developers via email and scheduled working sessions during IST hours. Customer will provide single point of contact details.
• *Publication Workflow Feedback*: Customer suggested adding a republish option in Forms UI to avoid unpublish/republish cycle. Engineering agreed to log enhancement request.
• *Adaptive Form Testing Update*: Customer reported offshore developer successfully created and modified adaptive forms. Team is progressing towards broader adoption of Forms Experience Builder.

:todo_done: *

• *AEM Forms Integration with Adobe Experience Platform (AEP):* Harman, Mayank, and Katie Manarte discussed the end-to-end process of integrating AEM forms with Adobe Experience Platform, including schema creation, data set configuration, and form setup, with Vince and other team members contributing questions and clarifications.
• *Form Field Configuration and Validation:* Katie Manarte inquired about configuring specific form fields, such as checkboxes and validation rules, with Harman and Mayank confirming that these options are available and customizable within the AEM editor.
• *Documentation and Support Resources:* Katie Manarte requested access to both written and video documentation for the integration process, with Harman and Vince confirming that comprehensive resources, including step-by-step videos, are available and will be shared.
• *Future Form Use Cases and Additional Integrations:* Mayank and Katie Manarte discussed potential future forms and other integration needs, agreeing to gather requirements and schedule further discussions or demos as needed.
:todo_done: *

*
• *Implementation of Custom Functions for Tracking IDs:* Andy, Mayank, Speaker 1, and the team discussed the implementation of custom functions to capture Facebook click ID, Google click ID, and Adobe Analytics ECID, with Speaker 1 demonstrating the code and deployment process, and clarifying the need for website team involvement for deployment.
• *Setting Up Rules for Operating Unit Selection:* Mayank and Speaker 1 described the process for parsing the address URL to determine the operating unit (such as US or Australia) and explained how custom rules can be created for this purpose, with Andy requesting assistance to ensure correct setup.
• *Access Issues with Git Repository and Developer Involvement:* Mayank, Christy, and Speaker 1 discussed ongoing access issues with the Git repository required for deploying custom functions, with Christy attempting to troubleshoot login problems and agreeing to escalate the issue to the security team, while Arun and others highlighted the importance of involving developers in the process.
• *Deployment Process and Client Library Integration:* Speaker 1 and Christy discussed the technical steps for integrating the custom client library into the codebase, including file structure, deployment to the QA environment, and the need to register the client library in form settings.
• *Coordination and Handover for Next Steps:* The team, including Andy, Mayank, Christy, and Speaker 1, agreed on next steps for sharing code, resolving access issues, and coordinating with the operations and developer teams to finalise the implementation and testing of custom functions and rules.

*Key Topics:*
• *Introduction:* Matthew, Arun, Vijay Kumar, and Chris from Adobe met with Laura, Dipesh Shrestha, and James from Centene to discuss the VIP project for implementing forms on edge delivery services. The meeting aimed to understand Centene's use cases, identify key forms for implementation, and explore potential collaboration opportunities. 
• *Centene Team Introductions:* Laura, Dipesh Shrestha, and James introduced themselves and their roles at Centene. Laura is a senior manager over the product side, Dipesh is an engineering manager overseeing two engineering teams, and James is a product management lead in the Experience Cloud organisation. 
• *VIP Program Overview:* Arun explained the VIP program, which involves a joint development team working together to get initial forms live on edge delivery services. The program includes regular meetings, a Slack channel, and a focus on integrating forms with existing systems of record. 
• *Forms Use Cases:* James and Laura discussed their respective use cases for forms on the secure portal and public side. James mentioned the need for forms in secure portal experiences, while Laura highlighted the need for forms on the public side, including new forms and existing forms with uploads. 
• *Technical Considerations:* The team discussed technical considerations, including the use of MongoDB and FileNet for storing form data, the need for forms to be embedded within pages, and the potential use of headless forms and cross-channel implementation. 
• *Conversational Forms Demo:* Chris provided a quick demo of conversational forms, showcasing the ability to fill forms through a chat interface and image uploads. This feature is in co-innovation mode and not yet out-of-the-box functionality. 
• *Next Steps:* The team agreed to identify one or two forms for the VIP engagement, share the URLs of the target forms, and explore the potential for co-innovation on conversational forms. Arun emphasised the importance of making the forms implementation repeatable and reusable.

Details
● I*nova Account Migration to Adobe* Eric Van Geem provided an overview of the Inova account, noting that they are an AEM Forms customer with approximately 180 forms on their current <http://inova.org|inova.org> site, which is hosted on Drupal. The team is in the process of migrating everything to Adobe, specifically utilizing AEM Forms and Edge Delivery Services to build the new site. The goal is to understand options for integrating AEM Forms with their existing systems, including parallel submissions to Eloqua and AEP
● *AEM Forms and Edge Delivery Services Capabilities* Vijay Kumar confirmed that all submit actions, except for the "assign task" step within AEM workflow, are supported on Edge Delivery Services. Vijay Kumar also stated that both Eloqua and AEP connectors are available out of the box, with Eloqua using a REST API and API using a direct connector. The team can offer assistance in setting up and configuring forms for multiple submission endpoints through their VIP program, similar to past collaborations.
● *VIP Program for AEP Connectors and Project Timeline* Vijay Kumar explained that the VIP program for AEP connectors is currently running, with new AEP and Marketo connectors recently introduced. They stated that participation in the VIP program requires a committed go-live date within a few weeks of starting the program. Eric Van indicated that while Inova is committed to going live, development on the site and forms has not yet begun, with a projected go-live date of July or August next year, following discovery, design, and a year-long development phase.
● *Azure Blob Storage Support for Form Attachments* Eric Van Geem inquired about storing signature images, specifically mentioning Azure blob storage as a potential option. Vijay Kumar confirmed that Azure blob storage is supported out of the box for attachments, allowing for configurations where attachments are sent to Azure blob storage while other data goes to AEP and Eloqua. They also mentioned that the process for configuring AEP connectivity is being streamlined to be more user-friendly and avoid multiple manual steps.
● *Ongoing Collaboration and Future Engagements* Eric Van Geem and Vijay Kumar agreed to coordinate on Slack to initiate the VIP program when the development of forms begins, acknowledging that content pages and other integrations might be prioritized initially . Vijay Kumar also inquired about Eric Van Geem's continued engagement with the "stereicycle" account, to which Eric Van Geem responded that their team is still involved in maintenance, though their personal allocation has shifted, with potential for future opportunities related to DA - universal editor approaches.

• We showed how to create a servlet that integrates the OSGi service for rendering PDFs in a local setup. We had previously shared a private FAR for this via an Adobe CRM ticket, and Ashish from NFCU was able to make it work in the meeting.
• We informed them that their cloud environments — Dev, Dev2, and SQA — have been updated with the latest requested changes.
Few new features have been requested
• Unit conversion from mm to cm within the canvas.
• Typography enhancements — specifically adding superscript and subscript formatting options.
• Switch one component to another. For example, if a user has added a textfield with content, they should be able to convert it into a numeric field while retaining the content. Though this functionality exists in the desktop designer — but do we really need to support this? 
• Text overflow handling for textfields — if a caption or value is too long, the container should auto-expand to accommodate the content.
• Batch PDF generation — not an immediate priority, but we discussed the current behavior and the potential need for batch processing in future render scenarios.
:todo_done: *

• *Demonstration of Form Creation and Import Capabilities:* Anurag demonstrated to Daniel Stöckli and Michael Peter the current capabilities for creating adaptive forms from scratch, importing forms via screenshots or hand-drawn images, and converting Acro and XFA PDF forms, highlighting the use of LLM for field detection and mapping.
    ◦ *Screenshot and Hand-Drawn Import:* Anurag explained and demonstrated how users can import screenshots or hand-drawn images into the adaptive forms editor, where an LLM identifies fields and maps them to form components, supporting both single and multiple image uploads.
    ◦ *PDF Form Conversion:* Anurag described the process of importing Acro forms and XFA PDF forms into the form manager, where the system analyzes the PDF and creates an adaptive form, with recent support added for XFA PDFs.
    ◦ *Uniform Editor Experience:* Anurag clarified that the import and creation capabilities are available in both the universal editor and adaptive forms editor, ensuring a consistent user experience across interfaces.
    ◦ *Field and Script Handling:* Anurag noted that while field mapping and detection are robust, script analysis and migration from PDF forms are not yet implemented, and are recognized as a significant area for future development.
• *Current State and Roadmap for Script Migration and Testing Automation:* Daniel Stöckli and Michael Peter inquired about the status and timeline for JavaScript migration from PDF and XFA forms and automated testing capabilities, with Anurag confirming content migration is available, script migration is in POC, and testing automation is being explored for core component forms.
    ◦ *Script Migration Status:* Anurag confirmed that content migration for XDP and XFA forms is available, but JavaScript migration for Acro and XFA forms is still in the proof-of-concept phase, with no concrete timeline but an estimate of one to two months for initial results.
    ◦ *Testing Automation Efforts:* Anurag described ongoing work on automated testing utilities for core component forms, which involve recording end-to-end user flows and detecting test case failures, but noted that these utilities do not yet support foundation component forms.
    ◦ *Customer Feedback and Data Needs:* Anurag requested that Daniel and Michael provide information on their current testing practices, time spent on testing, and representative forms with JavaScript to help guide development and prioritization of script migration and testing features.
    ◦ *Timeline and Availability:* Anurag stated that the script migration feature is targeted for release within the year, likely in Q4, and encouraged the team to provide sample forms and scripts to accelerate the POC and ensure the solution meets real-world needs.

Abbott is encountering multiple conversion issues, as detailed in <https://wiki.corp.adobe.com/display/lc/PDF+Generator+Support+for+Office+2021+and+Acrobat+DC|this wiki page>
, during their environment upgrade from *Windows Server 2016 + Office 2016 + Acrobat Classic* to *Windows Server 2022 + Office 2021 + Acrobat DC*.
As outlined in the wiki, workarounds are available for the reported issues, and Abbott has agreed to adopt the approach of running the AEM server interactively (from the command line).
Previously, the customer required an exception approval to operate the server in command-line mode due to security restrictions. However, in their recent update, Abbott confirmed that this exception approval is no longer required.

We have discussed the following four options with the customer:
1. *Run server in command-line mode* – The customer has tried this approach and is currently performing testing in their environment. They have made progress with this approach and are continuing their validation to complete testing.
2. *Multi-threaded support with single user* – As mentioned in the <https://wiki.corp.adobe.com/display/lc/Action+Plan+for+Office+to+PDF+Conversions+and+PDF+Generator+Roadmap|PDF Generator Roadmap>, we implemented and shared update about solution that enables multi-threaded support with a single user while running the server as a service. This update was shared with the customer, and they provided positive feedback and confirmed their readiness. With this solution, Word and Excel conversions support multi-threaded execution, whereas PowerPoint remains single-threaded. The customer indicated a need for PowerPoint multi-threaded conversions as well for certain use cases. To achieve this, they plan to run the server in command-line mode(with multi-threaded conversion by a single user for Excel).
3. *Abbott application improvements* – Abbott shared their application code for evaluation, and we provided recommendations to improve throughput. However, at this stage, the customer is not planning to implement any changes and intends to revisit this after resolving the current issues.
4. *Long-term plans for Office conversions* – Abbott has requested Adobe to share its long-term roadmap and strategy for Office conversions.

• *Overview of Adobe AEM Forms Value Proposition:* Melissa, Mark, and Jared from Adobe provided Sunil, Williams-VZ, Ani, Kiran, and the Verizon team with a comprehensive overview of the value proposition, features, and differentiators of Adobe AEM Forms, focusing on interactive communications, integration, compliance, and collaboration capabilities.
• *Interactive Communications Features:* Melissa recapped the core features of AEM Forms’ interactive communications, highlighting a single source of truth, centralized management, business rule-driven workflows, automation to reduce manual effort and errors, flexible data integration, and governance with reusable templates and collaboration between IT and business users.
• *Scalability and Omnichannel Delivery:* Melissa explained that AEM Forms enables scalable document processing, supporting both on-demand and batch operations at high volume, and facilitates omnichannel experiences by allowing content deployment across digital and print channels with reusable templates and content fragments.
• *Integration and Compliance:* The team emphasized AEM Forms’ flexibility in integrating disparate data sources and maintaining compliance, with features such as pre-approved content, locked templates, and collaborative workflows that ensure governance and regulatory adherence.
• *Differentiators and Future Capabilities:* Melissa and Arun discussed differentiators such as empowering business users, upcoming Gen AI authoring (currently in early access), tight integration with Adobe Experience Cloud, and the platform’s ability to address both output and input use cases, providing a unified solution for future needs.
• *Comparison of On-Premise and Cloud Service Offerings:* Jared, Arun, and Melissa detailed the differences between Adobe AEM Forms’ on-premise and cloud service models for the Verizon team, covering entitlements, technical capabilities, user management, infrastructure, and the implications for AI features and integration.
• *On-Premise Model Details:* Jared outlined the on-premise proposal, which includes up to 360 million renditions per year, AEM Forms Portal, reader extensions, adaptive forms, interactive communications, integrations, and media library, with clarification from Arun that the charging model is based solely on renditions, not individual modules.
• *Cloud Service Model Details:* Jared described the cloud service offering, which also supports 360 million renditions per year but adds Cloud Manager for environment management, automated provisioning of production, stage, and dev environments, and Adobe-managed compliance and security for infrastructure.
• *User and Environment Management:* Arun clarified that on-premise allows unlimited local installations of the Forms Designer, while the cloud version includes both standalone and integrated designer tools with upcoming versioning support; disaster recovery and redundancy are managed by the customer on-premise but handled by Adobe in the cloud.
• *AI and Innovation Availability:* Todd, Arun, and Melissa explained that AI-driven features, such as Gen AI authoring and prompt-based template generation, are exclusive to the cloud service, with ongoing innovation and integration with other Adobe cloud solutions, while on-premise does not support these AI capabilities.
• *Technical Clarifications on Renditions, Templates, and Integration:* Sunil, Ani, Williams-VZ, and Arun engaged in a detailed technical discussion to clarify the definition of renditions, template management, asset handling, and integration options for both on-premise and cloud deployments.
• *Definition and Counting of Renditions:* Arun confirmed that a rendition is defined as a single generated document (not per page), regardless of whether it is a bill, letter, or other template, and applies to both digital and print outputs; repeated retrievals of the same stored document do not count as additional renditions if the document is not regenerated.
• *Template and Asset Management:* The team discussed that the Forms Designer is used to create templates, which are then uploaded to AEM; the Media Library is used for managing in-house assets such as icons and logos, and is not an external stock library, with asset search and management available within the repository.
• *Feature Inclusion and Additional Purchases:* Arun clarified that all listed features (e.g., Forms Portal, Designer, Media Library) are included in the base package, and the only charge is for the number of renditions; there is no need to purchase additional modules for the described use cases.
• *Integration and Batch Processing:* Arun explained that both API and batch processing are supported: on-premise uses local infrastructure for batch data and output, while the cloud version uses Azure Blob storage; both models support synchronous and batch operations, with the cloud offering additional integration benefits for multi-solution architectures.
• *Next Steps and Internal Decision Process for Verizon:* Sunil and Williams-VZ outlined Verizon’s plan to review the provided proposals, compare with existing Adobe assets, and conduct internal discussions regarding business case justification and funding, with Adobe offering support for business case development and follow-up in January.
• *Internal Review and Comparison:* Sunil stated that the Verizon team will review the provided pricing and feature slides, compare the proposed AEM Forms solution with existing Adobe assets already in use by Williams-VZ’s team, and determine which approach best fits their use case.
• *Business Case and Funding Considerations:* The team discussed the need to prepare a business case and secure funding for the proposed solution, with Sunil noting that the internal process will determine the channel and structure for funding, and that Adobe’s Digital Services group can assist with business case development at no cost.
• *Timeline for Follow-Up:* It was agreed that, due to the holiday period, the Verizon team will reconvene internally and plan to reconnect with Adobe in the second week of January to discuss next steps and any further questions.

• *XFT to Adaptive Forms Migration Process:* Paul provided Vijay Kumar, Sudhanshu, and Satya Deep with a comprehensive overview of the migration process from legacy XFT forms to adaptive forms for the State of Washington project, detailing the technical workflow, challenges, and the use of custom utilities and scripts.
• *Legacy System Overview:* Paul explained that the original system consisted of approximately 300 XFT forms created in a VB application called Forms Gen, which interacted with various backend systems and produced both input and output forms, with output forms being archived and printed for different outlets.
• *Migration Workflow and Tools:* The migration involves parsing XFT files using a custom Python script to extract fields, properties, and embedded VBScript logic, which are then compiled into a specification spreadsheet that forms the basis for adaptive form development.
• *Reusable Components and Theming:* Paul described the creation of reusable fragments for common elements such as names and addresses, the development of a common theme and template, and the use of client libraries and custom layouts to standardize and streamline adaptive form creation.
• *Output Form Generation and Packaging:* The process includes assembling document packages by combining adaptive forms with output templates (XDPs), leveraging assembler APIs, and integrating third-party libraries for PDF handling and redaction, with the final packages distributed or archived as required.
• *Specification and QA Process:* A detailed specification document is generated for each form, reviewed and approved by the client, and used as a reference for both development and QA, ensuring alignment and traceability throughout the migration.
• *Project Scale, Timelines, and Resource Allocation:* Vijay Kumar and Sudhanshu inquired about the overall scale, batch processing, and time estimates for form migration, with Paul clarifying the number of forms, batching strategy, and the breakdown of effort between adaptive and output forms.
• *Form Volume and Batching:* Paul stated that the project involves migrating approximately 300 input forms and 800 output forms, with work proceeding in batches of five to ten forms at a time, and the current contract targeting around 100 adaptive forms.
• *Time Estimates and Workflow:* The typical timeline for creating an adaptive form is two to four weeks, depending on complexity, with the process including specification generation, client review, and development, while output templates are generally simpler and can be created in a day.
• *Effort Distribution:* Paul explained that adaptive form development usually takes one to five weeks per form for a developer, while output template creation is much faster due to their static and repetitive nature, and that work on output forms can begin in parallel with adaptive form specification review.
• *Reuse and Efficiency Gains:* The team leverages existing forms and fragments to accelerate development, often modifying similar forms rather than starting from scratch, which reduces effort and increases velocity as the project progresses.
• *Automation, Utilities, and AI Opportunities:* Satya Deep and Sudhanshu discussed with Paul the evolution of migration utilities, the potential for cumulative improvements, and the possible application of AI to further streamline specification generation and logic extraction.
• *Utility Evolution and Pattern Matching:* Paul described how the custom Python script and associated Excel-based dictionary are incrementally improved by capturing and reusing common code patterns and logic, making the specification process more efficient over time.
• *Challenges with Legacy Code:* Despite automation efforts, significant variation in legacy VBScript and form logic limits the extent of automation, requiring manual review and interpretation, especially for unique or complex cases.

• *Project Management and Tracking:* The team uses two Jira systems—one internal and one customer-facing—for tracking development tasks and QA findings, with the project built using Maven, VS Code, and GitHub for version control and deployment.
